message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 genes are essential for the development and maturation of B and T cells, so turning off these genes in knock-out mice will result in a total lack of B and T cells. All other options are not directly related to the function of RAG1 and RAG2 genes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 are essential for the development and function of B and T cells. Knock-out of these genes will result in a total lack of B and T cells, leading to severe immunodeficiency. Defect of NADPH oxidase in phagocyte is associated with chronic granulomatous disease, absence of CD18 in leukocytes is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency, and asymptomatic mice would not be an expected outcome of knocking out RAG1 and RAG2 genes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 genes play a crucial role in the development of B and T cells in the immune system. If these genes are knocked out, the mice will have a total lack of B and T cells, leading to severe immunodeficiency. Option A is incorrect because it refers to a defect in NADPH oxidase, which is not related to RAG1 and RAG2 genes. Option C is incorrect because CD18 is a molecule involved in leukocyte adhesion, which is not directly related to B and T cell development. Option D is incorrect because the lack of B and T cells will lead to severe immunodeficiency and related symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 genes are essential for B and T cell development. Knock-out of these genes will result in a total lack of B and T cells. Option A is not relevant to RAG1 and RAG2 genes. Option C is related to leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which is caused by a different genetic mutation. Option D is not necessarily true as the absence of B and T cells can lead to various symptoms and complications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 are involved in V(D)J recombination, a process necessary for the development of B and T cells. Knocking out these genes will result in a total lack of B and T cells, as mentioned in option (B). The other options are not related to the function of RAG1 and RAG2.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 are responsible for the process of V(D)J recombination, which is important for the production of antigen receptors on B and T cells. Knocking out these genes will result in a total lack of B and T cells, as they will not be able to properly undergo V(D)J recombination and mature. Option A is unlikely because NADPH oxidase is involved in the respiratory burst, which is a separate process from V(D)J recombination. Option C is also unlikely because CD18 is a subunit of several different leukocyte integrins and is not directly related to B and T cell development. Option D is incorrect because the absence of B and T cells will result in a severe immunodeficiency and susceptibility to infections, which would not be asymptomatic.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 are essential genes for V(D)J recombination, which is necessary for the development of T and B lymphocytes. Knocking out these genes would result in a total lack of B and T cells, leading to severe immunodeficiency. Defects of NADPH oxidase or absence of CD18 in leukocytes are unrelated to RAG1/2 function. The mice may not necessarily be asymptomatic, depending on the severity of the immunodeficiency and any potential secondary infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 are responsible for the process of V(D)J recombination, which is crucial in the development of B and T cells. Therefore, turning off these genes in mice would result in a total lack of B and T cells, leading to severe immunodeficiency. Options A and C are unrelated to this experiment, and option D cannot be determined as there may be other effects on the mice beyond the expected changes in immune function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 are necessary for the development of B and T cells, so a knock-out of these genes would result in a total lack of B and T cells. The other options are not related to RAG1 and RAG2 function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. RAG1 and RAG2 are important genes involved in V(D)J recombination, which leads to the development of B and T cells. Knocking out these genes would result in a total lack of B and T cells. The other options are not related to the function of RAG1 and RAG2.
